docs.lead_paragraph: Seasonal vegetables get a rich, spicy coating in this flavorful tostada topping.

headline.seo: Vegetable Tostadas With Dark Chili-Garlic Sauce — Recipes for Health
headline.main: Vegetable Tostadas With Dark Chili-Garlic Sauce

docs.snippet: Seasonal vegetables get a rich, spicy coating in this flavorful tostada topping.

docs.lead_paragraph: Give the stove the night off; other than toasting the tortillas, no cooking is required for these light and zesty tostadas.
docs.snippet: Give the stove the night off; other than toasting the tortillas, no cooking is required for these light and zesty tostadas.

docs.lead_paragraph: Fishing companies are increasingly drawn to the Southern Ocean, where the krill population is one of the least exploited.

headline.seo: Tracking Antarctic Krill as More Is Harvested for Omega-3 Pills
headline.main: Team Tracks a Food Supply at the End of the World
headline.print_headline: Team Tracks a Food Supply at the End of the World

docs.abstract: Oceanographers and environmentalists are increasingly drawn to the Southern Ocean near the Antarctic Peninsula, to study and protect one of the world's least exploited havens for krill, critical to marine ecosystems; area's krill are now threatened by climate change, as well as a growing flood of commercial fisherman intent on harvesting them for use as animal feed and human dietary supplements.
docs.snippet: Fishing companies are increasingly drawn to the Southern Ocean, where the krill population is one of the least exploited.

docs.lead_paragraph: Operating on the brain is usually seen as a last resort when drugs fail, but a new study suggests that having surgery sooner may prevent irreversible damage.

headline.main: Surgery for Epilepsy Gains Urgency in Trial
headline.print_headline: Surgery for Epilepsy Gains Urgency in Trial

docs.abstract: Dr Jerome Engel Jr study in The Journal of the American Medical Association suggests that epilepsy patients should undergo surgery as soon as possible after the failure of anti-epilepsy drugs, rather than pursuing continued medical care.
docs.snippet: Operating on the brain is usually seen as a last resort when drugs fail, but a new study suggests that having surgery sooner may prevent irreversible damage.

keywords.value: Journal of the American Medical Assn
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: An article in The Lancet suggests that pulling on the umbilical cord, or controlled cord traction, does not significantly reduce blood loss in women and may in fact endanger them.

headline.seo: Study Says Umbilical Cord Shouldn’t Be Pulled During Labor
headline.main: Childbirth: A Different Way to Remove the Placenta May Save Mothers’ Lives, a Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Childbirth: A Different Way to Remove the Placenta May Save Mothers’ Lives, a Study Finds

docs.abstract: Study published in journal The Lancet finds that common midwife practice in Africa and Asia of removing the placenta by pulling on the umbilical cord does not reduce risk of hemorrhage for the mother and carries other unnecessary risks.
docs.snippet: An article in The Lancet suggests that pulling on the umbilical cord, or controlled cord traction, does not significantly reduce blood loss in women and may in fact endanger them.

keywords.value: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
keywords.name: glocations

docs.lead_paragraph: A new analysis found that each daily increase of three ounces of red meat was associated with a 16 percent increased risk of cardiovascular death and a 10 percent increased risk of cancer death.

headline.seo: Red Meat Linked to Cancer and Heart Disease
headline.main: Risks: More Red Meat, More Mortality
headline.print_headline: Risks: More Red Meat, More Mortality

docs.abstract: Dr Frank B Hu study in Archives of Internal Medicine finds that eating red meat is associated with a sharply increased risk of death from cancer and heart disease.
docs.snippet: A new analysis found that each daily increase of three ounces of red meat was associated with a 16 percent increased risk of cardiovascular death and a 10 percent increased risk of cancer death.

docs.lead_paragraph: Accountable care organizations, a new kind of health care practice, are gaining momentum in part because of the Affordable Care Act signed into law two years ago.

headline.seo: With Small-Picture Approach, A.C.O.’s Gain in Health Care

docs.abstract: Accountable care organizations, collections of medical providers who band together under one business umbrella and are paid to care for a group of patients rather than being reimbursed for specific medical services, are gaining momentum in part because of the Affordable Care Act; ACOs have a powerful incentive to provide forward-looking and high-quality care, because they are allowed to keep and divide savings when patients remain healthy.
docs.snippet: Accountable care organizations, a new kind of health care practice, are gaining momentum in part because of the Affordable Care Act signed into law two years ago.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: The authors of a new analysis suggest that circumcision eliminates the possibility of germs flourishing in the moist environment under the foreskin, and thereby reduces the chance for infection.

headline.seo: Report Says Circumcision May Reduce Risk of Prostate Cancer
headline.main: Prevention: Prostate Risk Is Lower After Circumcision
headline.print_headline: Prevention: Prostate Risk Is Lower After Circumcision

docs.abstract: Analysis by Jonathan L Wright published in journal Cancer finds evidence that circumcision may reduce the risk for prostate cancer.
docs.snippet: The authors of a new analysis suggest that circumcision eliminates the possibility of germs flourishing in the moist environment under the foreskin, and thereby reduces the chance for infection.

docs.lead_paragraph: A seven-year study suggests a higher intake of vitamin D reduces stress fractures in girls 9 to 15.

headline.seo: Vitamin D Is Linked to Fewer Bone Fractures in Girls
headline.main: Childhood: Vitamin D Means Fewer Fractures for Girls
headline.print_headline: Childhood: Vitamin D Means Fewer Fractures for Girls

docs.abstract: Kendrin R Sonneville study published online in Archives of Pediatrics & Adolescent Medicine finds that higher amounts of vitamin D in the diet are associated with a lower risk for bone fractures in teenage girls.
docs.snippet: A seven-year study suggests a higher intake of vitamin D reduces stress fractures in girls 9 to 15.
